alert.note: Alert for Broward; Miami-Dade; Palm Beach (Florida) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued December 11 at 2:55PM EST by NWS Miami
info.description: ...Marginal Risk of Possible Flooding East Coast Areas Late This Week... The long range models are showing a stationary front over the Florida Straits to move northward and into South Florida late this week as high pressure slowly moves eastward over the Southeastern United States. At the same time, a low pressure system will start to form over the Central Gulf of Mexico. The low will continue to move northeast into the Southeastern United States, as the warm front moves into Central Florida next weekend. This weather pattern will allow for a southwest steering flow to set up over South Florida allowing for deep tropical moisture to work into the area from the Southern Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea. At the same time, the surface winds will be east northeast allowing for low level moisture to work into the east coast metro areas late this week before going south southwest this weekend. These two sources of moisture will allow for the PWAT values to increase to around 2 inches, which are near the maximum PWAT values for this time of year over South Florida. Therefore, there could be some heavy rainfall over the eastern areas of South Florida late this week into this weekend. At this time, it looks like rainfall amounts up to 5 inches are possible over the east coast metro areas late this week into this weekend with locally higher amounts where any heavy rainfall sets up due to training over the same area. Will continue to monitor the latest model forecasts through the week for the threat of heavy rainfall across the eastern areas of South Florida.
